conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, we need to analyze the motion of the particle based on the given acceleration-time and velocity-time graphs.

The acceleration graph shows a piecewise linear function with four segments: (1) From t = 0 to t = t0/2, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0. (2) From t = t0/2 to t = t0, acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0. (3) From t = t0 to t = 3t0/2, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -a0. (4) From t = 3t0/2 to t = 2t0, acceleration increases linearly from -a0 to 0.

The velocity graph shows how the velocity changes over time: (1) The velocity increases from 0 to a0*t0/2 at t = t0/2. (2) The velocity reaches a maximum of a0*t0/2 at t = t0. (3) The velocity decreases back to 0 at t = 2t0.

premise: The particle is farthest from the starting point when the velocity is at its maximum because the velocity is the rate of change of position.
conclusion: The particle is farthest from the starting point when the velocity is at its maximum.

premise: From the velocity graph, the maximum velocity occurs at t = t0.
conclusion: At t = t0, the particle reaches its maximum velocity, and hence, it is farthest from the starting point.
